results.title: Seachange = Sea change. Series 2. Ep. 8-13
results.brief_description: Series 2, episodes 8-13. “Manna From Heaven: (Dir: Steve Jodrell); Pearl Bay is being destroyed by a mysterious insect that has devoured Laura’s House, the courtroom and even the Tropical Star. Heather reveals her parent’s identity to the entire town and the town reveals a shocking secret. “Playing with fire” (Dir: Brendan Maher); Pearl Bay is suffering the effects of a heat wave; all the men in town become attracted to Laura; Miranda falls for a fireworks expert whose accused of being a pyromaniac and Kevin proposes to Phrani. “Not such great expectations” (Dir: Brendan Maher); Bob convinces Craig to leave school and follow in his footsteps; Laura worries about Rupert’s school marks and Miranda’s career indecision; and Max begins to write his book. “Kitty litter” (Dir: Paul Moloney); Laura discovers Trudi living with Jack and admits she is afraid of being replaced as their mother; Harold’s estranged wife, Cynthia, appears in court while Harold decides that its time he and Meredith married. “Other peoples’ opinions” (Dir: Paul Moloney); Max is seen leaving Laura’s house - via the bedroom window; Karen is left in charge of the police station while Sergeant Grey goes on holiday and she and Angus set a wedding date. Trevor goes missing and Phrani reveals a secret from her past. “Law and order” (Dir: Deb Cox , Paul Moloney); The bridge between Pearl Bay and Port Deakin is about to reopen, Laura decides to move back to the city, although Rupert and Miranda want to stay in the Bay. Bob joins the Port Deakin council and the courtroom is the scene of a siege.

results.title: Seachange = Sea change. Series 2. Ep. 1-7
results.brief_description: Series 2, episodes 1-7. “If fish could fly” (Dir: Ali Ali); Pearl Bay is once again isolated from Port Deakin following the destruction of the bridge in an unpredictable storm. Kevin is sued by a backpacker who lost his manuscript in the storm, and Laura and Dan officially become a couple. “Vaya Con Dios to all that” (Dir: Ali Ali); Bob is summoned to court for failing to lodge a tax return, Angus is attracted to the new tax prosecutor, who is more interested in Bob, Dan tries to persuade Laura to leave Pearl Bay and travel the world with him and Rupert runs away. “Broken hearts and crustaceans” (Dir: Mandy Smith); Max Connors arrives back in the bay, bringing his wife Elena who dreams of a happy reunion between Max and his father. Heather reveals the truth about her birth parents to Bob and the people of Pearl Bay lose their savings when Bob makes a shady deal. “Sink or swim” (Dir: Mandy Smith); Laura compares her failed relationships to Max and Elena’s happy marriage. Rupert and Trevor’s friendship is endangered by a paper route, and Bob becomes the town hero when he recovers the missing money. “Head for water” (Dir: Sue Brooks); the town is grieving over Elena’s death when Bucket’s dog is found drowned in the Pearl Bay swimming pool. Carmen returns to Pearl Bay and convinces Max to start a local newspaper and Angus is upset by the disappearance of the sandbar. “The house that Jack built” (Dir: Sue Brooks); the town is being threatened by monster crabs; Jack begins to build his house in Port Deakin, Laura receives a letter from Elena who asks her to be there for Max and Trudi makes a shocking announcement. “Looking forward to the past” (Dir: Steve Jodrell); The town are shocked when Bob arranges for a multinational corporation to sponsor the annual “Pearl Bay Port Festival” and Karen fears she may lose Angus when his ex-girlfriend arrives in town. Guest stars include Robert Grubb and Nicki Wendt.

results.title: Seachange = Sea change. Series 1. Ep. 8-13
results.creator_credit: Sally Ayre-Smith, ABC-TV (Australia) and Artist Services
results.brief_description: Episodes 8-13 of the captivating series “Sea Change” set in the idyllic coastal town of Pearl Bay. The episodes included are “My Own Sweetheart” (directed by Sue Brooks), “Balls and Friggin Goodluck” and “The Accidental Activist” (both directed by Mandy Smith) and “Love Me Or Leave Me”, “Perchance To Dream” and “Sex, Death and Bridges” (directed by Paul Moloney). The series excels not only because of the great writing but the wonderful gallery of characters created by an excellent cast. Stars Sigrid Thornton, David Wenham and John Howard with guest appearances by Bill Hunter, Robert Grubb, Trudy Hellier, Jeremy Callaghan and John Flaus.

results.title: Seachange = Sea change. Series 1. Ep. 1-7
results.creator_credit: Sue Brooks, Ali Ali, Ray Argall, Michael Carson, Sally Ayre-Smith, ABC-TV (Australia) and Artist Services
results.brief_description: Corporate lawyer Laura Gibson (Sigrid Thornton), and her two children find themselves moving from the city to the country when Laura’s marriage falls apart, her husband is imprisoned for embezzlement, and Laura misses out on a partnership. Reluctantly, and with dreams of picking up her life of disarray she begins a position as magistrate in the seaside community of Pearl Bay. They discover that the idyllic location harbours secrets which manifests itself in strange machinations. This tape includes the first seven episodes and stars Sigrid Thornton, David Wenham, John Howard, Bruce Alexander, Kate Atkinson, Kerry Armstrong, and Alice Garner. Episodes directed by Michael Carson, Ray Argall, Ali Ali and Sue Brooks.

results.creator_credit: Donna Kendrigan and Victorian College of the Arts
results.brief_description: Exquisitely animated journey into a forgotten, grinding ocean, where a weeping boat carries a haunting past.

results.title: Sea wife
results.creator_credit: Bob McNaught, Andre Hakim and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Cast adrift during wartime in the Indian Ocean after a bombing raid on their ship, an RAF officer (Richard Burton) and a nun (Joan Collins) in civilian clothing find themselves attracted to each other. Fighting off attacks by sharks and surviving in the harsh sun, the couple are forced together to brave the elements. The nun gives the officer no encouragement, but he falls madly in love with her and vows to find her again when they return to civilisation. Will she keep her vocation a secret or will she give in to her desires? Based on the novel ‘Sea-Wyf’ by J.M. Sott.

results.title: Sea safety
results.creator_credit: Ian Williams and National Recording Studios
results.brief_description: During the 1986 Australian premier blue water event, the Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race, crew members faced the worst weather conditions in living memory. Many yachts sought shelter, crew members were injured and one man was lost overboard. Sea-Safety Canberra, assisted by 4 fixed wing aircraft, mounted an unsuccessful search which covered more than 2,500 square kilometres. Each year Sea-Safety covers approximately 1,800 incidents, including ships running aground, cargo vessels adrift, pleasure craft in trouble. This video looks at the methods employed, and the resources available, in order to maintain efficient and prompt sea safety services to all who require them. Narrated by David Allen.

results.title: Sea road
results.brief_description: Three times a week the “Princess of Tasmania” leaves Melbourne for Devonport. Carrying up to 100 cars and 300 passengers, the ship’s crew deal efficiently and cheerfully with both people and vehicles. We see the passengers and transports loaded, overnight accommodation, and the offloading in the morning.

results.title: Sea Raider [original release]
results.creator_credit: Louis Ralph, Ken G. Hall and First National Pictures
results.brief_description:
‘Sea Raider’ is a reconstruction of an earlier film, ‘The Exploits of the Emden’ (Louis Ralph, Ken G. Hall, 1928) which opened in Sydney’s most prestigious cinema, the Prince Edward, on 21 September 1928. It ran in the cinema for three weeks, making it a considerable success. ‘Exploits of the Emden’ was itself a partial reconstruction as it combined new footage shot by Ken G. Hall with footage from the German film ‘Unsere Emden’ (Louis Ralph, 1926).
While the reasons for releasing a condensed version of the film are unclear, ‘Sea Raider’ appears to have been intended as a supporting short for ‘Exploits of the Emden’.
‘Sea Raider’ has removed most of the previous two films’ scenes of character development to provide a straightforward dramatised documentary that covers the career of SMS ‘Emden’ and its conflict with HMAS ‘Sydney’ in November 1914. Intertitles describe ‘Sea Raider’s sequence of events.
Source: Byrnes, Paul ‘Curators Notes’ on ‘The Exploits of the Emden’. Australian Screen [aso.gov.au]
(Accessed 23rd March, 2015)
